180 Longwood Avenue
BOSTON, MA 02115

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care.
citations.narrative:
On 2/3/25 veterinary staff administered the anesthetic drug ketamine to one non-human primate for a routine veterinary
care procedure. The anesthetic administered was 3 days beyond the label expiration date of 1/31/25. According to the
animal’s record and veterinary staff, the animal was adequately anesthetized during the procedure and did not experience
any harmful effects from the administration of the ketamine.
Per this Section, each research facility shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the
use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases or injuries. The use of medications that are
past the manufacturer’s expiration date is not considered providing adequate veterinary care. This incident was self-
reported to OLAW and the research facility addressed this incident prior to the inspection by modifying the handling and
monitoring of controlled substances to identify any medications that are approaching near-term expiration dates to ensure
they are not used past their expiration date. No additional incidents have occurred. To remain corrected from this date
8/12/25 forward.
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with facility representatives.
*END OF REPORT*
n

narrative:
2.33(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care. 
On 2/3/25 veterinary staff administered the anesthetic drug ketamine to one non-human primate for a routine veterinary 
care procedure. The anesthetic administered was 3 days beyond the label expiration date of 1/31/25. According to the 
animal’s record and veterinary staff, the animal was adequately anesthetized during the procedure and did not experience 
any harmful effects from the administration of the ketamine.  
 
Per this Section, each research facility shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the 
use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases or injuries. The use of medications that are 
past the manufacturer’s expiration date is not considered providing adequate veterinary care. This incident was self-
reported to OLAW and the research facility addressed this incident prior to the inspection by modifying the handling and 
monitoring of controlled substances to identify any medications that are approaching near-term expiration dates to ensure 
they are not used past their expiration date. No additional incidents have occurred. To remain corrected from this date 
8/12/25 forward. 
 
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with facility representatives.  
 
*END OF REPORT*
